results.headline: When Deal Wobbles, a Double Steps In
results.summary_short: In “The Lookalike,” a noir with many characters, a woman and her double become involved with drug dealing.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lookalike

results.headline: A Wheeler-Dealer Turned Broker for Racial Justice
results.summary_short: The documentary “Plot for Peace” centers on a French commodities trader who helped broker a peaceful end to apartheid in South Africa.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Plot for Peace

results.headline: Ravaged by Time, a Steel Town Tries to Hold On
results.summary_short: “Braddock America” chronicles the troubles of Braddock, Pa., a steel town that has seen better days.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Braddock America

results.headline: At 21, Fighting to Help Lead a Troubled City
results.summary_short: “True Son” is a portrait of a violence-ridden California city sharply segregated by race and income and the Stanford senior who ran for a City Council seat.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of True Son

results.headline: Two Brothers, One War and Separate Fates
results.summary_short: Two brothers from rural England find different fates amid the trenches on the Western Front in “Private Peaceful,” based on a novel by Michael Morpurgo, of “War Horse.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Private Peaceful

results.headline: The First Responder Is a Cameraman
results.summary_short: In “Nightcrawler,” Jake Gyllenhaal plays a freelance videographer who tries to corner the market on grisly images of crime and accident scenes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nightcrawler

results.headline: Look! I’m Just Like Lawrence of Arabia
results.summary_short: Marshall Curry’s documentary “Point and Shoot” seems to turn the tables on its subject, an American who joined the fight against Muammar el-Qaddafi in Libya.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Point and Shoot

results.headline: That’s Some Dollhouse!
results.summary_short: Jeremy Workman’s “Magical Universe” is a home-video introduction to Al Carbee and his odd, glam Barbie photography.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Magical Universe

results.headline: Suddenly, He’s Father Confessor
results.summary_short: In “Horns,” starring Daniel Radcliffe, people start confessing their evil desires and doings to a young man after he suddenly sprouts horns.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Horns

results.headline: The Perils of Online Dating
results.summary_short: “Hit by Lightning” is a parody of “Double Indemnity” involving a man (Jon Cryer) venturing into online dating only to meet a femme fatale.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hit By Lightning

results.headline: Vampires Without Coffins
results.summary_short: “Blood Ransom” follows a beautiful vampire-in-the-making as she goes on the run with a mortal man who loves her.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blood Ransom

results.headline: The Pain of Polygamy
results.summary_short: “Bitter Honey,” a documentary by the U.C.L.A. anthropologist Robert Lemelson, examines an island that remains mired in ancient patriarchy and domestic violence.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bitter Honey

results.headline: Pushing the Usual Buttons
results.summary_short: The Good Morning School for Burmese children in Thailand is the subject of Stuart Cameron’s documentary “All You Need Is Love.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of All You Need Is Love

results.headline: A Life Not Gone, Just Forgotten
results.summary_short: In “Before I Go to Sleep,” Nicole Kidman plays an amnesiac who awakens each day not knowing who she is, nor the man lying beside her (Colin Firth).

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Before I Go To Sleep

results.headline: Far-Flung, Long-Lasting and Still Punk at the Core
results.summary_short: The Joe Angio documentary “Revenge of the Mekons” shows how a band went beyond its punk roots and explored other art forms.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Revenge of the Mekons

results.headline: Lots of Philosophy, No Inhibitions
results.summary_short: In “Goodbye to Language,” Jean-Luc Godard weaves narratives around a man, a woman and a dog.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Adieu au langage

results.headline: Disaster’s Toll on the Gulf and Its People
results.summary_short: “The Great Invisible,” a documentary by Margaret Brown, focuses on the everyday people whose lives were disrupted by the BP oil spill in 2010.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Great Invisible

results.headline: A Bollywood Specialty: Caper Movie, With Extras
results.summary_short: “Happy New Year” stars Shah Rukh Khan as a fighter intent on stealing a bad-guy diamond dealer’s gems during a dance competition in Dubai.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Happy New Year

results.headline: Pet’s Slaughter Uncorks a Latent Inner Assassin
results.summary_short: In “John Wick,” a thriller starring Keanu Reeves, the protagonist resumes his career as an assassin after villains break into his home and kill his dog.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of John Wick

results.headline: Every Man for Himself! Forget the Wife and Kids
results.summary_short: In Ruben Ostlund’s “Force Majeure,” a father flees what he thinks is an avalanche, but the family he leaves behind is not amused.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Force Majeure
